utterances: : Is it possible to use Facebook and still be private?
The short answer is no.
: Thank you very much.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
: Well, people go - so they're making a social bond, right?
Do they - do the people understand how public they are going to be when they're on Facebook?
You know, I don't believe that they do.
And I think one of the things that really surprised me, when I start researching this book, was so many people didn't understand.
Part of that I think is due to the Facebook people.
They come out and they say upfront, you know, that it's private, it's secure.
They really promote that idea that you're in this just this big room with all your friends and what goes on in Facebook stays there.
But, of course, some has not - that's not quite the whole story.
: But there - aren't there lots of little switches and toggles in there that you can adjust what everybody gets to see?
There are, and this week Facebook announced a few more.
Unfortunately, according to Facebook, only one out of four people can find those little toggles and then actually goes and toggles them.
And...
: Wow.
...the difference - what they added this week was they made it a little more complex.
I guess...
: More complex?
Well, no more - how do we put it?
You can do more with it, with the feature and...
: The power user will like it.
Yes.
: But for most of us, we don't know it's there and we probably don't take the time to even look at it before.
No, it's administrative stuff.
People get on Facebook to do fun stuff, that's like going online and having somebody say, well, now go do your taxes before you can have any fun.
: Let's get into some - maybe this is some of the stuff that you're talking about.
This week, Facebook unveiled some changes that let you restrict what you share to different sets of friends, right?
Before you had just one friend, everybody's your friend, and now, we have different sets of friends.
You can group people into, for instance, friends from work or friends from college and only let each - one see certain things.
Is that what you're talking about?
That is exactly what I'm talking about.
They always - or at least for a long time, they've had that capability.
This is just an expansion of that capability.
And you know, of course, the problem with that is, of the one out of four people who's actually going to do it, it's a little more complex now.
And of course, now you have to decide, well, is this is my work buddy, you know, I go get - I have beer with himm after work, too.
What group do I put him in?
: Mm-hmm.
And of course, when you get more friends you have to go remember to stick them in a group.
So...
: Yeah.
Alessandro, I know you studied Facebook, also.
What is reaction to this?
I actually agree with Emily.
In studies we did published in 2005 and 2006, we did find out that at the time, the users we sampled had misconceptions about the visibility of their profiles.
They thought that the profile was accessible by X people, while in fact we knew because we could check it was accessible by - in all the magnitude(ph), the larger amount of people.
Also, there is what economists called the carousel of options.
When you do too - when you give too many options to individuals, they end up - they tend to make a suboptimal choice, which means that control on your setting is a good thing.
However, too granular control can end up a being a boomerang, because it can end up overtaking the ability of the user to really control his or her privacy.
So, yes, control is good, but don't put all the responsibility on the user, because it is also an important issue what is their default setting of those controls.
: Yeah.
(Soundbite of music)
Absolutely.
And that's one thing I start off the book saying, there's no such thing - if you put anything on the Internet - period, you've lost control over it.
And I think Facebook does an admirable job of giving you guidance.
You can guide the site on what you - who you would like to see the information go to or not.
But it is not secure.
And even the terms of use of the Facebook, they come out and say that they're not responsible if it all goes missing.
So...
: Mm-hmm.
And if it's - go ahead.
Well, you know - so I think that that's certainly sound advice if you want to be cautious.
And some people would want to be cautious and some people have really sensitive information that I'm sure they don't want exposed.
So there's no question people have to be aware of the risks that they face today on these kinds of - in these kinds of environments.
I think, though, that we should really aspire to do somewhat better than this.
Because if you try to map this discussion that we're having about people needing to protect themselves and you really can't expect anyone - anything's private...
: Mm-hmm.
...into other parts of our lives, say, our - you know, our academic records at school, or banking records or our health records.
You know, we'd all be in a state of utter paralysis.
We - none of us would do anything if we all felt that we are at risk of total exposure at every moment.

And I think that - while I agree that it's great that Facebook is experimenting with these extra options, I think that it's really true what Alessandro said that over and over again what we see with computer software in general, is that people don't change the defaults.
And I think we've really put the burden in the wrong place when it comes to privacy protection.
We've expected that if people don't take active steps to protect their personal information, it must mean anyone can do anything with it.
And I think that that's just the wrong assumption to make.
It's not the assumption, I think, at the end of the day that other users ought to make, it's just to be, sort of, it's not polite.

And I think, ultimately, there ought to be legal protections that establish some kind of boundaries that people can rely on without having to, you know, guard their - all of their personal data by themselves.
: Mm-hmm.
Let's go to John(ph) in Phoenix.
Hi.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Hi.

My question is, is anyone concerned with the idea that by having this younger generation that I'm actually a part of, you know, that are using the MySpaces and the Facebooks and have been posting personal information since they were 13, do you think that's going to breed a younger generation - or going to breed a generation of people who are less concerned with their own personal security and their - all their information being out there because they've been doing it for so long?
: Could you...
You know, I think it's really interesting.
The older generation is, I think, jumping on the behavior patterns of the younger generation in trying to draw a lot of conclusions.
Many of which, I actually think, are inaccurate.
There have been some very good studies by the PEW Center on Internet Life which does a lot of polling on the way that people use, for example, the Web and social networks.
And what they find is that people actually do have pretty subtle expectations.
They don't want all the data that they put on a social network to be exposed for use in any way by anyone.
I think Emily is, I'm sure, right that they may have misconceptions about what the rules actually are.
But I don't think that we should assume that just because people live somewhat more public lives, that they can - that it's okay to do anything at all with their personal information.
: So you think that Facebook needs to step up to the plate here...
Well...
: ...and take more responsibility for the information that we give them?
I think that Facebook should - I think that it's actually a larger problem.

I think that we, as a society, really have to come to some agreements about things like, use of this sort of information in employment context, use in financial context, use where it's really sensitive where it can really hurt us.
And, yes, I think we have to invest more both in, you know, on the legal side.

I think the good news is that there are organizations like the National Science Foundation that are starting to fund a lot of research into this area to understand all the different dimensions of privacy, both the technical direction - dimensions and the legal and sociological dimensions.
So, we have to just pay more attention to this.
I think we'll learn a lot from what Facebook does.
And I think they clearly have an interest in getting this right.
I don't think they're going to be able to do it all by themselves.

: Emily, what caution should people who are - who get messages from people in Facebook and say, hey, poke me or send me an e-mail or something, if you return those invitations, do you open yourself up?
You do.

If somebody pokes you or sends you an e-mail message or otherwise, approaches you and you respond, you've just given them access to your profile, even though they might otherwise, even if you're one of those one out of four people that blocked them before.
What you do in the case of somebody stalking, Facebook's got little links that you can go and report somebody and, of course, they can get kicked off the site.
So - but, yeah, you do have to expect that.
: Could you - should you expect that if you close up your site, that Facebook will not keep the information?
I think you should expect that they will keep the information.
And there was a big stink about this in the press a couple of weeks ago, and people were saying, wow, you know, we can't get off the site; they're going to archive information.
But, you know, my response to that is, this site is not free, you don't pay with - for it with money, you pay for it with your personal information.
And they're using this - this is not society, this is a company that intends to make money off of it.
They have no motivation to leave your, you know, to delete your information and there's no vetting(ph) process to find out whether or not they do or not.
: Mm-hmm.
